author: Erin Gallagher
title: Body of youngest saint visits Orland Park church Daily Southtown
text:
It's common for the Roman Catholic faithful to visit the relics in Italy of the church's youngest saint, Maria Goretti, but this week her remains, encased in a wax statue, will visit the Southland.
As part of a 16-state tour, Goretti's skeletal remains will visit St. Francis of Assisi Church, 15050 Wolf Road, Orland Park on Wednesday and St. Mary Immaculate Church, 15629 Illinois 59 in Plainfield on Thursday.
The statue of Goretti in a glass casket covers a nearly complete skeleton of the 11-year-old girl, known as the Little Saint of Great Mercy, who was stabbed to death in 1902 by a 20-year-old neighbor after she had resisted his sexual advances for months, according a St. Mary's brochure about the event.
Church officials say Goretti's importance as a saint stems from at least two reasons. First, her last words were to forgive her attacker, which caused him to convert to Catholicism and later become a Franciscan lay brother, according to a website on the U.S. pilgrimage.
"She is known for forgiving even in the midst of her physical suffering," Edward Flavin, director of communication for the Joliet Diocese, said.
Second, Goretti is attributed with having performed the most miracles, the brochure says.
"As for how miracles are attributed to St. Maria Goretti or any saint, a person was sick, a cure was out of the question, prayers were directed to a particular person (not necessarily yet a saint or even beatified), the sick person is cured and doctors have no natural explanation for it," Flavin wrote in an email.

(WGN-TV) See more videos Goretti's casket is touring the U.S., first making several stops in the Midwest, including Chicago and Northlake earlier this week.
Nikolai Medow, spokesman for St. Mary's Parish, said the timing of the tour coincides with Pope Francis' Year of Mercy, which begins Dec. 8 during the feast of the Immaculate Conception.
Public viewings of the casket are available at both churches. At St. Francis of Assisi, the veneration is from 9 a.m. to midnight, Wednesday with a Mass at 7 p.m. In Plainfield Thursday, veneration is from 10 a.m. to the 11 p.m. night prayer. There will be a rosary at noon and 9 p.m., a Divine Mercy Chaplet at 3 p.m., and a Mass at 7 p.m.
For more information about Saint Maria Goretti and the U.S. tour, visit www.mariagoretti.com .
Erin Gallagher is a freelance reporter.
